entry.title: Re: Direct configuration in test tenant/production tenant
entry.content:
Dear @snigdhodeep,

The Lexicographical indicator in Define Output Format of Material Numbers (102320) cannot be switched ON or OFF once any purely numeric product/material numbers exist in that system. SAP blocks it with message BMG265 (Numeric material numbers already exist in system) because changing the rule would make existing numbers ambiguous / not interpretable

SAP Note below:

https://me.sap.com/notes/0003516603

In Public Cloud (3-system landscape) you also can‚Äôt just maintain it directly in Test/Production to bypass transports, business configuration is provided via SAP Central Business Configuration (CBC) connected to DEV, and then moved via the transport tools/process to Test/Prod

SAP Note below:

https://me.sap.com/notes/0003482742

In my opinion you have two options:

Option A: Recommended if you‚Äôre still in implementation / test data)

To change the Lexicographical setting, you must get to a state where no numeric product numbers have been used yet. SAP own guidance is archive/remove the numeric materials first only then can you change the indicator. In real projects this usually means one of these approaches depending on what‚Äôs feasible in your tenant and how much dependent data exists:

  • Refresh/reset the DEV/customizing tenant or request a clean tenant and set Lexicographical before any product creation/migration, then re-migrate
  • If you already created products and even transactions, deletion is often messy the clean tenant + re-load approach is usually the least risky

SAP Note below:

https://me.sap.com/notes/0003516603

Option B: Accept SAP product number behavior and introduce a business-facing ID for example Custom Field. If you cannot remove those numeric product numbers, then you cannot solve this by changing Lexicographical so a workaround can be:

  • Add/repurpose a field for the business product code that must keep meaningful leading zeros for example a dedicated custom field like ZZ_EXT_PROD_CODE or a standard legacy/old product number style field if it fits your governance
  • Use that field in:
    • migration templates / interfaces,
    • search/display in Fiori apps as a visible column and filter,
    • outputs/printing/integration mappings

This is the only safe path if production data must remain intact.

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: AI-Assisted User Learning and Change Management is ready
entry.content:
Sometimes in SAP projects, I meet people who look at the long list of tools we have today and ask a completely reasonable question: ‚ÄúWe already use Joule. We already use SAP Enable Now. We already use WalkMe. Do we really need something else for user learning?‚Äù

If you are not an L&D specialist, this question makes perfect sense. At first glance, everything seems to overlap. And this is usually the moment where curiosity starts, because something feels unclear, even for experienced project leaders.

What most people don‚Äôt see is everything that happens long before training materials appear on the screen. We all know the visible part: videos, simulations, in-app guidance, Joule answering questions.

But behind the scenes, there is a much harder challenge that quietly decides whether a project succeeds or fails. It‚Äôs the work of figuring out what users actually need to learn. Not in theory, but in their company, with their processes, their roles, their variations, with their data and their way of working. This part is slow, manual, and often messy. And people only realize how heavy it is once they sit down and try to build a training plan from scratch.

This is the gap the AI-assisted user learning and change management app is designed to fill. It doesn‚Äôt try to replace Joule or WalkMe or SAP Enable Now. It solves a completely different problem; one that these tools don‚Äôt address.

While Joule helps users on the spot when they have a question, and WalkMe and SAP Enable Now help deliver learning and guidance, none of them tells you what the learning should look like in the first place unless you spend considerable amount of effort to achieve that golden goal. 

User adoption often becomes harder than expected because the real challenge is not creating training materials; it is understanding what people actually need to learn. And this understanding must come from the organization‚Äôs trusted sources of truth: the business processes designed in SAP Signavio, the user stories written during the project, the test cases stored in SAP Cloud ALM, and all the other documents teams create along the way. Bringing these pieces together, making sense of them, and turning them into clear learning steps for every role is slow, if manual, and easy to get wrong. This hidden work is the real reason training becomes complicated and why projects struggle to keep learning aligned, accurate, and up to date.

This is exactly where the AI-assisted user learning and change management app steps in; it connects all these sources, analyzes them, and helps transform complex project information into a structured, role-based learning path that users can follow.

The simplest way I can describe it is this: the app gives direction. Joule supports users in the moment. WalkMe and SAP Enable Now bring the training to life. Each one has its own job. When they‚Äôre used together, they make the learning experience smoother, clearer, and far easier to manage‚Äîboth for learners and for the teams delivering the project.

If you‚Äôre not from the learning world, skepticism is normal. But once you see the hidden work behind user adoption, the value becomes obvious. Most of the pain in training doesn‚Äôt come from producing content. It comes from figuring out what the content should be.

For the first time, this can be automated. And that is why the AI-assisted user learning and change management app is not ‚Äúanother tool.‚Äù It's the complementary link that ties everything together and turns learning into something that finally fits the real world of SAP projects.

The AI-assisted user learning and change management app is commercially available (in limited delivery through the Early Adopter Care program) starting December 8th, 2025, making this capability accessible to SAP customers.

Key resources

  • Custom LNA

  • Prepare Learning Content
  • SAP Store 
  • SAP Discovery Center ‚Äì AI Feature
  • SAP Business AI Estimator

entry.title: Understanding PO Deletion and Service Entry Behavior in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud
entry.content:
Hi Team,

Could you please assist in confirming whether our understanding is accurate?

Limit PO (Services)

  • ECC Behavior: Deletion is not permitted after invoicing; this ensures strict audit control.
  • S/4HANA Public Cloud Behavior: Deletion is allowed even after invoicing.

Rationale for Standard Behavior

  • Material vs. Service POs
    • Material POs: Deletion is restricted post-invoice to preserve inventory and valuation accuracy.
    • Service Limit POs: These framework POs do not affect inventory postings, so SAP permits deletion after invoicing as it does not impact stock or material ledger.

Main Reasons

  • Services do not impact inventory.
  • Allows flexibility for recurring or contract-based services.
  • Invoices remain valid in FI even if the PO is deleted.

Blocked PO Line

  • ECC Behavior: Changes are restricted once the line is blocked.
  • S/4HANA Public Cloud Behavior: Service Entry updates and deletions remain possible.

Rationale for Standard Behavior

  • Blocking a PO line prevents new procurement actions but does not prohibit modifications to service entries.
  • Service Entry Sheets (SES) validate service delivery and impact accounting, not inventory.
  • SAP allows SES corrections for enhanced flexibility and audit compliance.

Design Rationale

  • Materials: Stringent controls are in place due to inventory and valuation considerations.
  • Services: More flexibility is provided as these do not affect stock.
  • Blocking halts new confirmations but permits adjustments to existing SES for accuracy.

ECC vs S/4HANA Public Cloud Behavior Comparison

Scenario ECC Behavior S/4HANA Public Cloud Behavior

Standard PONo deletion after invoicing; audit trail maintainedDeletion not allowed after invoicing
Limit PO (Services)No deletion after invoicing; strict audit controlDeletion allowed even after invoicing (by design)
Blocked PO LineChanges restricted once blockedService Entry updates/deletes still possible

Regards,

Sai.

entry.title: Re: Unable to Assign G/L Account Ranges to Semantic Tags
entry.content: Assigning G/L account ranges to semantic tags isn‚Äôt supported. To proceed, either assign the semantic tag at the FSV item level so all accounts under the node inherit it, or remove the account range from the FSV and list the accounts individually so each one can be tagged separately.

entry.title: Dynamic Font Styling in Adobe Forms (JavaScript)
entry.content:
Introduction:
In many business scenarios, Adobe Forms need to highlight specific information dynamically‚Äîsuch as marking certain values in bold, keeping others in normal, or changing the emphasis based on data conditions. Instead of hard-coding text styles, we can control the font style at runtime using simple logic. This approach makes the form more readable, user-friendly, and aligned with business rules.

while assigning font style in adobe forms we have provision to select font style thats applied each of the data, but what if i has to maintain dynamically means based on condition? this blog will gives solution.

Solution Overview:
To implement dynamic font styling in Adobe Forms, the value to be evaluated is passed into the form, and a small JavaScript condition is added in the text field‚Äôs event (such as initialize or exit). In this script, the field‚Äôs value is checked, and based on the condition, the font weight is adjusted at runtime. For example, if the value equals ‚ÄúGTARLANA,‚Äù the script sets the text to bold, otherwise it applies a normal font style. This simple logic allows the form to adapt its appearance dynamically without modifying the layout each time a new rule is introduced.

if ( this.rawValue === "GTARLANA" ){
       this.font.weight = "bold"
       };
       else{
       this.font.weight = "normal" };

Output:

 

When condition Satisfied

 

When condition not Satisfied

 



Conclusion:
Dynamic font styling in Adobe Forms provides a clean way to highlight important data without complicating the form layout. By controlling style through conditions, you maintain a single design while achieving dynamic visual emphasis. This approach is simple, reusable, and enhances the clarity of printed business documents.

entry.title: Re: How can I get a complete list of sub-scope items prog...
entry.content:
Hello,

Sorry for the delay in getting back to you,

If this is still relevant, the most effective "single downloadable file" approach is to use a structured export report directly from SAP Signavio Process Manager, as this is the primary source for detailed process modeling. You should use the Process Characteristics Report with Detailed Elements from SAP Signavio Process Manager.  This report generates an Excel file (XLS) containing a structured, tabular view of all elements and attribute values within the selected diagrams.

This report will also help you to get the applications (Apps) and roles associated with each process step (sub-scope item), you rely on the same comprehensive data sources used above, provided that the required linkages are maintained as attributes or relationships in your tools.

For this to work efficiently, the roles and applications must be modeled as attributes (standard or custom) associated with the respective BPMN elements (tasks, sub-processes, etc.) in SAP Signavio Process Manager.

 

If your organization relies on SAP LeanIX to model the complex relationships between processes, applications, and roles (a key function of Enterprise Architecture Management), using its APIs is the best programmatic approach:
SAP LeanIX Data Model: The process structure (sub-scope items) is documented on the Business Context Fact Sheet, and these Fact Sheets can be explicitly linked to:
    ‚ó¶ Applications (Apps): Using the direct relationship between Business Context (Process) and Application Fact Sheets.
    ‚ó¶ Roles: Roles are often modeled as Organization Fact Sheet subtypes (like "Team" or "Business Unit"), which are linked to applications, or as Subscription Roles (Responsible/Accountable) on the Fact Sheets themselves.
‚Ä¢API Usage: You can use the GraphQL API or the OData Integration to query these complex, multi-layered relationships in bulk.
 
You can then queries relationships between Process Fact Sheets (sub-scope items), Application Fact Sheets, and associated Organization/User Group data in bulk, mitigating manual effort/slow file downloads.
 
Do not hesitate to reach out to the following email to get further support: signavio_success@sap.com
Best,

entry.title: Re: How to Calculate VAT for PO and get in the Standard f...
entry.content:
Good day @Yathurshika_Sathiyavarman

The BAdI you are using has limited access to the pricing and tax condition values. Direct access to condition types like MWST is not provided in it.

The error you experienced often refers to improper syntax or usage of fields that are not available in that context.

You cannot directly retrieve Tax, Net or Gross Amount by using the BAdI you mentioned in public cloud because pricing data is not available at this enhancement point.

I recommend following the extensibility-compliant method:

Step 1:

Create a CDS view with I_PurchseOrderItemAPI01 and associate it with A_PurOrdPricingElement to retrieve condition values and filter it for VAT-relevant condition types in the CDS logic or within the Form.

Step 2:

You need to extend your PO Form Data Source. Use the Maintain Form Template Data Source Extensions. Here, choose MM_PUR_PO_OUTPUT, create a new extension by joining your CDS and the item and publish.

Step 3:

In the Manage Form Templates App, copy MM_PUR_PURCHASE_ORDER, download the Adobe Lifecycle Designer, add your Custom VAT field and add sum logic for VAT in Adobe (e.g., JavaScript logic)

Step 4:

Finally upload the form template you modified back into the Manage Form Templates App, assign it to the MM_PUR_PO_OUTPUT type and ensure your communication arrangement and output channel are active.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: How to get ModelID in Signavio Process Governance?
entry.content:
Hello

The most likely cause of the "ModelID is not defined" error is that the modelID variable is not properly defined or not available in the JavaScript task. In Process Governance, workflow variables must be explicitly defined and selected before a script can use them.

  1. Check variable access in the script task, make sure modelID is selected in the task configuration. If it isn‚Äôt included as an input, the script cannot read it and the error appears.

  2. Make sure the Model ID is provided earlier in the workflow, for example by the workflow trigger or a previous action that passes the model ID and revision ID.

  3. Use the SAP Signavio Process Manager API client in your script, import the library, then query the model details using the modelID once the variable is correctly passed.

If this did not help please reach out to signavio_success@sap.com

Best,
